title: 113_hr1613
content: The Act is titled the "Outer Continental Shelf Transboundary Hydrocarbon Agreements Authorization Act" and it amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act by adding a section on transboundary hydrocarbon agreements. After the enactment of the Outer Continental Shelf Transboundary Hydrocarbon Agreements Authorization Act, the Secretary is authorized to implement transboundary hydrocarbon agreements approved by Congress to promote domestic job creation and ensure the orderly development of mineral resources on the outer Continental Shelf. A transboundary hydrocarbon agreement must be submitted to Congress within 180 days of all parties agreeing to its terms. The Secretary must submit a transboundary hydrocarbon agreement to key Congressional members, including the Speaker of the House and the Chair of relevant committees. The submission should include any necessary amendments to federal law and an analysis of the economic impacts on domestic exploration. The Secretary may implement the terms of the Transboundary Hydrocarbon Agreement with Mexico, including approving unitization agreements for oil and gas exploration in transboundary reservoirs. The Secretary may implement the terms of the Transboundary Hydrocarbon Agreement with Mexico, including approving unitization agreements for oil and natural gas from transboundary reservoirs or geological structures, sharing confidential information, following expert determinations, and authorizing appropriate inspection staff to stop work on installations. The lessee has the authority to stop work on any installation or vessel attached to the seabed for resource exploration, development, or production activities. Public companies following transboundary hydrocarbon agreements are exempt from reporting requirements. The Secretary is not authorized to participate in negotiations with Cuba regarding hydrocarbon exploration. The United States has sovereign rights over the Gulf of Mexico and the Eastern Gap for hydrocarbon exploration, development, and production activities. The Agreement between the United States and Mexico regarding Transboundary Hydrocarbon Reservoirs in the Gulf of Mexico, signed in 2012, is approved.
